Description: Shoulder sherd of Attic black-figured pottery amphora or hydria; interior glazed black on neck, reserved below; exterior: black band on ridge at turn of neck; frieze of short tongues at top of shoulder; below, black-figure decoration consisting of a horse to right (head remaining, with added red on mane and a male, probably charioteer, also to right, head turned back (upper body remaining, with sleeveless chiton in added white). In the field part of a pre-firing dipinto and some random(?) incised lines.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The shape recalls Panathenaic amphoras, but the format of decoration is different. If this is two (or more chariots) in a race, the space needed suggests a broad field.
Bibliographic references: CVA Brussels III / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Belgique (p. 21, pl. 28, no. 8)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0916)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Purchased in Cairo by M. Jean de Mot
